questions.question: What, according to you, is the primary advantage of using multiple antennas at the transmitter/receiver?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Multiple antennas do not inherently increase battery life; they may even increase power use.
explanations.b: Correct! Multiple antennas improve reliability by mitigating fading through spatial diversity and beamforming.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Multiple antennas generally make the receiver more complex.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Multiple antennas usually increase hardware costs, not reduce them.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes spatial diversity in wireless communications?

answers.a: Using different time slots to send the same signal
answers.b: Using different frequency bands to transmit data
answers.c: Using multiple antennas sufficiently spaced to transmit/receive signals
answers.d: Using encryption techniques to secure the communication

explanations.a: Incorrect. This is time diversity, not spatial diversity.
explanations.b: Incorrect. This is frequency diversity, not spatial diversity.
explanations.c: Correct! Spatial diversity uses multiple antennas placed apart to reduce fading and improve reliability.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Encryption deals with security, not diversity.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of beamforming in MISO and MIMO systems?

answers.B: To direct the transmission energy towards specific users

explanations.A: Incorrect. Beamforming can improve power efficiency but its main role is to focus energy toward a target direction.
explanations.B: Correct! Beamforming shapes the transmitted signal spatially to maximize signal strength at the intended user and reduce interference elsewhere.
explanations.C: Incorrect. Beamforming usually increases transmitter complexity.
explanations.D: Incorrect. Modulation order is unrelated to beamforming.

questions.question: When is equal gain combining (EGC) used?

answers.A: No CSI at transmitter, but CSI present at receiver

explanations.A: Incorrect. This is more typical for maximal ratio combining (MRC).
explanations.B: Incorrect. EGC does not require CSI at both transmitter and receiver.
explanations.C: Correct! EGC can be applied when only phase information is known at the receiver, without full channel gain knowledge.
explanations.D: Incorrect. There is a defined condition when EGC is applicable.

questions.question: What is the array gain of Equal Gain Combining (EGC)?

explanations.A: Correct! EGC normalizes amplitude, so the gain factor compared to MRC is reduced to 1 in normalized SNR terms.

questions.question: Which combining technique is less efficient when implemented in hardware?

answers.C: Depends on the number of antennas

explanations.A: Incorrect. EGC is more efficient in terms of performance compared to selection combining.
explanations.B: Correct! Selection combining uses only the strongest branch, wasting the potential contributions from other antennas.
explanations.C: Incorrect. SC is generally less efficient regardless of antenna count.

questions.question: Which of the following most accurately describes the Alamouti scheme?

explanations.A: Incorrect. Alamouti is not purely a combining method.
explanations.B: Correct! Alamouti’s scheme is a 2×1 orthogonal space-time block code for transmit diversity.
explanations.C: Incorrect. It is not a standard error-correcting code.

questions.question: Which of the following is computationally the most complex?

explanations.A: Incorrect. SC is the simplest to implement.
explanations.B: Incorrect. EGC is less complex than MRC because it does not require amplitude weighting.
explanations.C: Correct! MRC requires precise channel estimation and optimal weighting, making it computationally the most demanding.
